title: The touching moment World War II veteran is honoured by Vitesse captain
text:
The captain of Dutch football team Vitesse made a touching tribute to an Operation Market Garden veteran on Saturday night to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Arnhem.

The operation was a World War II mission to help liberate the Nazi-occupied Netherlands by using troops on the ground to access key bridges and roads into Germany.

Despite a brutal assault by Nazi tanks thwarting the operation, it did help to liberate some areas of the Netherlands and is remembered for the remarkable courage shown by the Allied forces. 7,500 soldiers either died or were made prisoners of war.

The captain of Vitesse Arnhem made touching tribute to Operation Market Garden veteran

Bryan Linssen ran into the crowd to present the war hero with his shirt and shake his hand

Linssen also took off his captain's armband and placed it over the top of the veteran's suit

Thousands of fans in the crowd celebrated the veteran before the game kicked off in Vitesse

Operation Market Garden inspired the celebrated film 'A Bridge too Far', which was based on a book of the same name and had an all-star cast including Dirk Bogarde, Michael Caine, Sean Connery, Anthony Hopkins, Laurence Olivier and Robert Redford. The title is a reference to a comment apparently made to Field Marshall Montgomery stating that the mission might fail, saying 'I think we may be going a bridge too far.'

To mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Arnhem, which was at the vanguard of the Allied operation, many of those involved were invited guests to watch the Eredivisie game between Vitesse and Fortuna Sittard on Saturday night.

After treating them to a 4-2 victory, Vitesse captain Bryan Linssen, who scored twice, ran into the crowd to present a veteran with his shirt.

He took off the jersey and handed it to the former soldier before Linssen also removed his captain's armband and slid it onto the veteran's arm.

The pair then exchanged a few words before posing for pictures in front of the celebratory crowd at the GelreDome.

Speaking about the celebration, Linssen said: 'It's very special and nice that we have been able to honour these veterans this way.

'They have done a lot for all of us in the Netherlands. Chapeau! I thanked him for everything he's done for us.'

Fans unfurled a huge banner that depicted five paratroopers landing next to a bridge

A soldier also abseiled from one area of the stadium down to pitch level before the game

A group of academy players were stood in a V as the teams made their way out onto the pitch

It replicated a scene from a match against Ajax in 1942 when players stood in a V to pay homage Winston Churchill's famous 'V for Victory' gesture during World War II

Linssen's gesture was just one of many things that the club had planned to mark the occasion.

Fans also unfurled a huge banner behind one goal that depicted paratroopers landing next to a bridge to symbolise the operation.

A soldier also abseiled from one area of the stadium down to pitch level and the veterans were also cheered by the crowd of thousands by the side of the pitch before the game started.

A group of Vitesse academy players were also stood in a V as the teams made their way out onto the pitch. This was to replicate a scene from a match against Ajax in 1942 when players also stood in a V to pay homage to the 'V for Victory' gesture that Winston Churchill made with his fingers during World War II.

Vitesse scored three times in the final 10 minutes to secure all three points. They are now up to third in the Eredivisie table behind Ajax and PSV Eindhoven.
description: The captain of Dutch team Vitesse made a touching tribute to an Operation Market Garden veteran on Saturday night to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Arnhem.
